factoid: Natásha reflected that she was not better than she had formerly imagined.
Natásha reflected that she was worse than anybody else in the world.
Natásha reflected that she was much worse than anybody else in the world.
The comfort Natásha received was not enough.
Natásha knew that the comfort was not enough.
Natásha asked herself what next.
There was nothing to come.
There was no joy in life.
Life was passing.
Natásha tried not to be a burden to anyone.
Natásha tried not to be a hindrance to anyone.
Natásha wanted nothing for herself.
Natásha kept away from everyone in the house.
Natásha felt at ease only with her brother Pétya.
Natásha liked to be with her brother Pétya better than with the others.
Natásha sometimes laughed when alone with her brother Pétya.
Natásha hardly ever left the house.
Pierre was glad to see Natásha.
It would have been impossible to treat Natásha with more delicacy than Count Bezúkhov did.
It would have been impossible to treat Natásha with greater care than Count Bezúkhov did.
It would have been impossible to treat Natásha more seriously than Count Bezúkhov did.
Natásha unconsciously felt Count Bezúkhov's delicacy.
Natásha found great pleasure in Count Bezúkhov's society.
Natásha was not grateful to Pierre for his kindness.
Nothing good on Pierre’s part seemed to Natásha to be an effort.
Natásha thought that Pierre's kindness was natural and had no merit.
Natásha sometimes noticed embarrassment and awkwardness on Pierre's part in her presence.
Natásha noticed embarrassment and awkwardness on Pierre's part especially when he wanted to do something to please Natásha.
Natásha noticed embarrassment and awkwardness on Pierre's part especially when Pierre feared that something they spoke of would awaken distressing memories for Natásha.
Natásha noticed Pierre's embarrassment and attributed it to his general kindness and shyness.
Natásha imagined that Pierre's general kindness and shyness was the same toward everyone as it was toward Natásha.
After Pierre uttered involuntary words that if he were free he would have asked on his knees for Natásha's hand and her love, Pierre never spoke to Natásha of his feelings.
Natásha seemed to think that Pierre's words were spoken as meaningless words are spoken to comfort a crying child.
Natásha did not feel a moral barrier because Pierre was married.
Natásha had experienced the absence of a moral barrier with Kurágin.
Natásha thought that the relations between Pierre and Natásha could not lead to love on her part.
Natásha thought that the relations between Pierre and Natásha could not lead to love on Pierre's part.
Natásha thought that the relations between Pierre and Natásha could not lead to a tender, self-conscious romantic friendship.
Agraféna Ivánovna Belóva came to Moscow before the end of the fast of St. Peter.
Agraféna Ivánovna Belóva was a country neighbor of the Rostóvs.
Agraféna Ivánovna Belóva paid her devotions at the shrines of the Moscow saints.
Agraféna Ivánovna Belóva suggested that Natásha should fast and prepare for Holy Communion.
Natásha gladly welcomed the idea of fasting and preparing for Holy Communion.
Despite the doctor's orders that Natásha should not go out early in the morning, Natásha insisted on fasting and preparing for the sacrament.
Natásha did not prepare for the sacrament by attending three services in the Rostóv family house.
Natásha prepared for the sacrament by going to church every day for a week.
Natásha did not miss Vespers, Matins, or Mass during that week.
